bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to John Pemberton, April 12, 1732

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Liverpool mercvhant John Pemberton, April 12, 1732, to report the arrival of Captain Loxom in the Loyalty, and his pleasure that Captain Fowler, who arrived two weeks earlier, has told him that Pemberton will continue to handle Carter's tobacco as long as they "both remain on the Stage of the World." He also reports shipments of tobacco.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to John Pemberton, April 12, 1732

opener.dateline:
Rap[pahannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
April 12. 1732
Mr. John Pemberton

div1.p:
I have just now receiv'd yours by Capn: Loxum he hath
had 14 weeks passage Fowler hath been in this near a Fortnight he gave
me the pleasing Satisfaction to tell me that he heard you publickly
say you would transact business for me while we both remaind on
the Stage of this world

I sent you 50 hogsheads of stemm'd tobo in the True Blue cap B.
Berry who I hope by this time is near with you I purpose some more
to you by these Ships which shall be all the trouble I shall give yo. at
this time from

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1731 July 9-1732 July 13 , Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] Captain Loxom commanded a vessel named the Loyaltyin 1729-1730. (Survey Report 9727, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia. See Carter's letters to John Pemberton 1730 April 15 and 1731 August 4.)
